definition.en: JobTracker server memory size

description.en: Default size for jobtracker server memory.

definition.en: Total memory size for tasktracker map and reduce slot

description.en: Total memory size for tasktracker map and reduce slot.

definition.en: Default size for tasktracker server memory

description.en: Default size for tasktracker server memory.

definition.en: job history location

description.en: If job tracker is static the history files are stored in this single well known place. If No value is set here, by default, it is in the local file system at ${hadoop.log.dir}/history.

definition.en: user specified history location

description.en: User can specify a location to store the history files of a particular job. If nothing is specified, the logs are stored in output directory. The files are stored in "_logs/history/" in the directory. User can stop logging by giving the value "none".

definition.en: The completed job history files location

description.en: The completed job history files are stored at this single well known location. If nothing is specified, the files are stored at ${hadoop.job.history.location}/done.

definition.en: IO sort factor

description.en: The number of streams to merge at once while sorting files. This determines the number of open file handles.

definition.en: Total amount of buffer memory to use while sorting files,

description.en: The total amount of buffer memory to use while sorting files, in megabytes. By default, gives each merge stream 1MB, which should minimize seeks.

definition.en: The percentage of io.sort.mb dedicated to tracking record boundaries

description.en: The percentage of io.sort.mb dedicated to tracking record boundaries. Let this value be r, io.sort.mb be x. The maximum number of records collected before the collection thread must block is equal to (r * x) / 4

definition.en: buffer limit

description.en: The soft limit in either the buffer or record collection buffers. Once reached, a thread will begin to spill the contents to disk in the background. Note that this does not imply any chunking of data to the spill. A value less than 0.5 is not recommended.

definition.en: Number of index entries to skip between each entry

description.en: Number of index entries to skip between each entry. Zero by default. Setting this to values larger than zero can facilitate opening large map files using less memory.

definition.en: The host and port that the MapReduce job tracker runs at

description.en: The host that the MapReduce job tracker runs at. If "local", then jobs are run in-process as a single map and reduce task.

definition.en: The address that the job tracker runs at

description.en: The host and port that the MapReduce job tracker runs at. If "local", then jobs are run in-process as a single map and reduce task.

definition.en: The port that the MapReduce job tracker runs at

description.en: The port that the MapReduce job tracker runs at. If "local", then jobs are run in-process as a single map and reduce task.

definition.en: The port for jobtracker thrift server.

description.en: The port for jobtracker thrift server.

definition.en: The job tracker http server address and port

description.en: The job tracker http server address and port the server will listen on. If the port is 0 then the server will start on a free port.

definition.en: The number of server threads for the JobTracker.

description.en: The number of server threads for the JobTracker. This should be roughly 4% of the number of tasktracker nodes.

definition.en: The interface and port that task tracker server listens on

description.en: The interface and port that task tracker server listens on. Since it is only connected to by the tasks, it uses the local interface. EXPERT ONLY. Should only be changed if your host does not have the loopback interface.

property.name: mapred.local.dir

definition.en: MapReduce local directory

property.script: 'export dirs=`ruby /usr/lib/intelcloud/scripts/mounts.rb 2>/dev/null`;if [ "$dirs" == "" ]; then echo "/hadoop/mapred"; else for dir in $dirs; do echo $dir/hadoop/mapred; done; fi'

description.en: The local directory where MapReduce stores intermediate data files. May be a comma-separated list of directories on different devices in order to spread disk i/o. Directories that do not exist are ignored.

definition.en: The directory where MapReduce stores control files.

description.en: The directory where MapReduce stores control files.

definition.en: The root of the staging area for users' job files

description.en: The root of the staging area for users' job files In practice, this should be the directory where users' home directories are located (usually /user)

definition.en: A shared directory for temporary files.

description.en: A shared directory for temporary files.

definition.en: minimum space in mapred.local.dir to start task

description.en: If the space in mapred.local.dir drops under this, do not ask for more tasks. Value in bytes.

definition.en: mapred.local.dir minimum space kill

description.en: If the space in mapred.local.dir drops under this, do not ask more tasks until all the current ones have finished and cleaned up. Also, to save the rest of the tasks we have running, kill one of them, to clean up some space. Start with the reduce tasks, then go with the ones that have finished the least. Value in bytes.

definition.en: TaskTracker expiry interval

description.en: Expert: The time-interval, in miliseconds, after which a tasktracker is declared 'lost' if it doesn't send heartbeats.

definition.en: TaskTracker instrumentation class

description.en: Expert: The instrumentation class to associate with each TaskTracker.

definition.en: tasktracker resource calculator plugin

description.en: Name of the class whose instance will be used to query resource information on the tasktracker.The class must be an instance of org.apache.hadoop.util.ResourceCalculatorPlugin. If the value is null, the tasktracker attempts to use a class appropriate to the platform. Currently, the only platform supported is Linux.

definition.en: TaskTracker monitoring interval

description.en: The interval, in milliseconds, for which the tasktracker waits between two cycles of monitoring its tasks' memory usage. Used only if tasks' memory management is enabled via mapred.tasktracker.tasks.maxmemory.

definition.en: TaskTracker sleeptime before sending a SIGKILL

description.en: The time, in milliseconds, the tasktracker waits for sending a SIGKILL to a process, after it has been sent a SIGTERM.

definition.en: map count

description.en: The default number of map tasks per job. Ignored when mapred.job.tracker is "local".

definition.en: reduce count

description.en: The default number of reduce tasks per job. Typically set to 99% of the cluster's reduce capacity, so that if a node fails the reduces can still be executed in a single wave. Ignored when mapred.job.tracker is "local".

definition.en: TaskTracker out-of-band heartbeat

description.en: Expert: Set this to true to let the tasktracker send an out-of-band heartbeat on task-completion for better latency.

definition.en: out-of-band heartbeat damper

description.en: When out-of-band heartbeats are enabled, provides damping to avoid overwhelming the JobTracker if too many out-of-band heartbeats would occur. The damping is calculated such that the heartbeat interval is divided by (T*D + 1) where T is the number of completed tasks and D is the damper value. Setting this to a high value like the default provides no damping -- as soon as any task finishes, a heartbeat will be sent. Setting this parameter to 0 is equivalent to disabling the out-of-band heartbeat feature. A value of 1 would indicate that, after one task has completed, the time to wait before the next heartbeat would be 1/2 the usual time. After two tasks have finished, it would be 1/3 the usual time, etc.

definition.en: Whether enable job recovery

description.en: "true" to enable (job) recovery upon restart, "false" to start afresh

definition.en: The block size of the job history file

description.en: The block size of the job history file. Since the job recovery uses job history, its important to dump job history to disk as soon as possible. Note that this is an expert level parameter. The default value is set to 3 MB.

definition.en: The maximum permissible size of the split metainfo file

description.en: The maximum permissible size of the split metainfo file. The JobTracker won't attempt to read split metainfo files bigger than the configured value. No limits if set to -1.

definition.en: The class responsible for scheduling the tasks.

description.en: The class responsible for scheduling the tasks.

definition.en: The maximum number of running tasks for a job before it gets preempted

description.en: The maximum number of running tasks for a job before it gets preempted. No limits if undefined.

definition.en: Map maximum attempt times

description.en: Expert: The maximum number of attempts per map task. In other words, framework will try to execute a map task these many number of times before giving up on it.

definition.en: Reduce maximum attempt times

description.en: Expert: The maximum number of attempts per reduce task. In other words, framework will try to execute a reduce task these many number of times before giving up on it.

definition.en: The default number of parallel transfers run by reduce during the copy(shuffle) phase

description.en: The default number of parallel transfers run by reduce during the copy(shuffle) phase.

definition.en: reducer maximum fetch failures

description.en: The maximum number of times a reducer tries to fetch a map output before it reports it.

definition.en: reducer connect timeout

description.en: Expert: The maximum amount of time (in milli seconds) a reduce task spends in trying to connect to a tasktracker for getting map output.

definition.en: reducer read timeout

description.en: Expert: The maximum amount of time (in milli seconds) a reduce task waits for map output data to be available for reading after obtaining connection.

definition.en: task timeout value

description.en: The number of milliseconds before a task will be terminated if it neither reads an input, writes an output, nor updates its status string.

definition.en: The maximum number of map tasks that will be run simultaneously by a task tracker

description.en: The maximum number of map tasks that will be run simultaneously by a task tracker.

definition.en: The maximum number of reduce tasks that will be run simultaneously by a task tracker.

description.en: The maximum number of reduce tasks that will be run simultaneously by a task tracker.

definition.en: maximum number of complete jobs to keep around per user

description.en: The maximum number of complete jobs per user to keep around before delegating them to the job history.

definition.en: The limit on the input size of the reduce

description.en: The limit on the input size of the reduce. If the estimated input size of the reduce is greater than this value, job is failed. A value of -1 means that there is no limit set.

definition.en: The number of retired job status to keep in the cache.

description.en: The number of retired job status to keep in the cache.

definition.en: The number of job history files loaded in memory

description.en: The number of job history files loaded in memory. The jobs are loaded when they are first accessed. The cache is cleared based on LRU.

definition.en: JobTracker instrumentation class

description.en: Expert: The instrumentation class to associate with each JobTracker.

definition.en: Java opts for the task tracker child processes

description.en: Java opts for the task tracker child processes. The following symbol, if present, will be interpolated: @taskid@ is replaced by current TaskID. Any other occurrences of '@' will go unchanged. For example, to enable verbose gc logging to a file named for the taskid in /tmp and to set the heap maximum to be a gigabyte, pass a 'value' of: -Xmx1024m -verbose:gc -Xloggc:/tmp/@taskid@.gc The configuration variable mapred.child.ulimit can be used to control the maximum virtual memory of the child processes.

definition.en: The JVM heapsize used by each map task and reduce task.

description.en: The JVM heapsize used by each map task and reduce task.

definition.en: tasktracker child process environment variable

description.en: User added environment variables for the task tracker child processes. Example : 1) A=foo This will set the env variable A to foo 2) B=$B:c This is inherit tasktracker's B env variable.

definition.en: MapReduce maximum virtual memory

description.en: The maximum virtual memory, in KB, of a process launched by the Map-Reduce framework. This can be used to control both the Mapper/Reducer tasks and applications using Hadoop Pipes, Hadoop Streaming etc. By default it is left unspecified to let cluster admins control it via limits.conf and other such relevant mechanisms. Note: mapred.child.ulimit must be greater than or equal to the -Xmx passed to JavaVM, else the VM might not start.

definition.en: map virtual memory size

description.en: The size, in terms of virtual memory, of a single map slot in the Map-Reduce framework, used by the scheduler. A job can ask for multiple slots for a single map task via mapred.job.map.memory.mb, upto the limit specified by mapred.cluster.max.map.memory.mb, if the scheduler supports the feature. The value of -1 indicates that this feature is turned off.

definition.en: reduce virtual memory size

description.en: The size, in terms of virtual memory, of a single reduce slot in the Map-Reduce framework, used by the scheduler. A job can ask for multiple slots for a single reduce task via mapred.job.reduce.memory.mb, upto the limit specified by mapred.cluster.max.reduce.memory.mb, if the scheduler supports the feature. The value of -1 indicates that this feature is turned off.

definition.en: map maximum virtual memory size

description.en: The maximum size, in terms of virtual memory, of a single map task launched by the Map-Reduce framework, used by the scheduler. A job can ask for multiple slots for a single map task via mapred.job.map.memory.mb, upto the limit specified by mapred.cluster.max.map.memory.mb, if the scheduler supports the feature. The value of -1 indicates that this feature is turned off.

definition.en: reduce maximum virtual memory size

description.en: The maximum size, in terms of virtual memory, of a single reduce task launched by the Map-Reduce framework, used by the scheduler. A job can ask for multiple slots for a single reduce task via mapred.job.reduce.memory.mb, upto the limit specified by mapred.cluster.max.reduce.memory.mb, if the scheduler supports the feature. The value of -1 indicates that this feature is turned off.

definition.en: map virtual memory size

description.en: The size, in terms of virtual memory, of a single map task for the job. A job can ask for multiple slots for a single map task, rounded up to the next multiple of mapred.cluster.map.memory.mb and upto the limit specified by mapred.cluster.max.map.memory.mb, if the scheduler supports the feature. The value of -1 indicates that this feature is turned off iff mapred.cluster.map.memory.mb is also turned off (-1).

definition.en: reduce virtual memory size

description.en: The size, in terms of virtual memory, of a single reduce task for the job. A job can ask for multiple slots for a single map task, rounded up to the next multiple of mapred.cluster.reduce.memory.mb and upto the limit specified by mapred.cluster.max.reduce.memory.mb, if the scheduler supports the feature. The value of -1 indicates that this feature is turned off iff mapred.cluster.reduce.memory.mb is also turned off (-1).

definition.en: tmp directory for map and reduce tasks

description.en: To set the value of tmp directory for map and reduce tasks. If the value is an absolute path, it is directly assigned. Otherwise, it is prepended with task's working directory. The java tasks are executed with option -Djava.io.tmpdir='the absolute path of the tmp dir'. Pipes and streaming are set with environment variable, TMPDIR='the absolute path of the tmp dir'

definition.en: in-memory merge threshold

description.en: The threshold, in terms of the number of files for the in-memory merge process. When we accumulate threshold number of files we initiate the in-memory merge and spill to disk. A value of 0 or less than 0 indicates we want to DON'T have any threshold and instead depend only on the ramfs's memory consumption to trigger the merge.

definition.en: The usage threshold at which an in-memory merge will be initiated

description.en: The usage threshold at which an in-memory merge will be initiated, expressed as a percentage of the total memory allocated to storing in-memory map outputs, as defined by mapred.job.shuffle.input.buffer.percent.

definition.en: memory to store map outputs during the shuffle

description.en: The percentage of memory to be allocated from the maximum heap size to storing map outputs during the shuffle.

definition.en: The percentage of memory- relative to the maximum heap size- to retain map outputs during the reduce

description.en: The percentage of memory- relative to the maximum heap size- to retain map outputs during the reduce. When the shuffle is concluded, any remaining map outputs in memory must consume less than this threshold before the reduce can begin.

definition.en: whether to execute multiple instances of map task in parallel

description.en: If true, then multiple instances of some map tasks may be executed in parallel.

definition.en: whether to execute multiple instances of reduce task in parallel

description.en: If true, then multiple instances of some reduce tasks may be executed in parallel.

definition.en: Number of taks to run per jvm

description.en: How many tasks to run per jvm. If set to -1, there is no limit.

definition.en: The minimum size chunk that map input should be split into

description.en: The minimum size chunk that map input should be split into. Note that some file formats may have minimum split sizes that take priority over this setting.

definition.en: The maximum number of tasks for a single job

description.en: The maximum number of tasks for a single job. A value of -1 indicates that there is no maximum.

definition.en: The replication level for submitted job files

description.en: The replication level for submitted job files. This should be around the square root of the number of nodes.

definition.en: The name of the Network Interface from which a task tracker should report its IP address

description.en: The name of the Network Interface from which a task tracker should report its IP address.

definition.en: TaskTracker name server address

description.en: The host name or IP address of the name server (DNS) which a TaskTracker should use to determine the host name used by the JobTracker for communication and display purposes.

definition.en: The number of worker threads that for the http server

description.en: The number of worker threads that for the http server. This is used for map output fetching

definition.en: The task tracker http server address and port

description.en: The task tracker http server address and port. If the port is 0 then the server will start on a free port.

definition.en: Whether to keep files for failed tasks

description.en: Should the files for failed tasks be kept. This should only be used on jobs that are failing, because the storage is never reclaimed. It also prevents the map outputs from being erased from the reduce directory as they are consumed.

definition.en: Whether to compress job output

description.en: Should the job outputs be compressed?

definition.en: compress type of job outputs

description.en: If the job outputs are to compressed as SequenceFiles, how should they be compressed? Should be one of NONE, RECORD or BLOCK.

definition.en: job outputs compress codec class

description.en: If the job outputs are compressed, how should they be compressed?

definition.en: Whether to compress map outputs

description.en: Should the outputs of the maps be compressed before being sent across the network. Uses SequenceFile compression.

definition.en: map outputs compression class

description.en: If the map outputs are compressed, how should they be compressed?

definition.en: The default sort class for sorting keys.

description.en: The default sort class for sorting keys.

definition.en: The maximum size of user-logs of each task in KB

description.en: The maximum size of user-logs of each task in KB. 0 disables the cap.

definition.en: user log maximum retain hours

description.en: The maximum time, in hours, for which the user-logs are to be retained after the job completion.

definition.en: The maximum allowed size of the user jobconf

description.en: The maximum allowed size of the user jobconf. The default is set to 5 MB

definition.en: Names a file that contains the list of nodes that may connect to the jobtracker.

description.en: Names a file that contains the list of nodes that may connect to the jobtracker. If the value is empty, all hosts are permitted.

definition.en: Names a file that contains the list of hosts that should be excluded by the jobtracker

description.en: Names a file that contains the list of hosts that should be excluded by the jobtracker. If the value is empty, no hosts are excluded.

definition.en: Approximate number of heart-beats that could arrive at JobTracker in a second

description.en: Expert: Approximate number of heart-beats that could arrive at JobTracker in a second. Assuming each RPC can be processed in 10msec, the default value is made 100 RPCs in a second.

definition.en: TaskTracker maximum number of blacklists

description.en: The number of blacklists for a tasktracker by various jobs after which the tasktracker will be marked as potentially faulty and is a candidate for graylisting across all jobs. (Unlike blacklisting, this is advisory; the tracker remains active. However, it is reported as graylisted in the web UI, with the expectation that chronically graylisted trackers will be manually decommissioned.) This value is tied to mapred.jobtracker.blacklist.fault-timeout-window; faults older than the window width are forgiven, so the tracker will recover from transient problems. It will also become healthy after a restart.

definition.en: The timeout (in minutes) after which per-job tasktracker faults are forgiven

description.en: The timeout (in minutes) after which per-job tasktracker faults are forgiven. The window is logically a circular buffer of time-interval buckets whose width is defined by mapred.jobtracker.blacklist.fault-bucket-width; when the "now" pointer moves across a bucket boundary, the previous contents (faults) of the new bucket are cleared. In other words, the timeout's granularity is determined by the bucket width.

definition.en: TaskTracker fault timeout window bucket width

description.en: The width (in minutes) of each bucket in the tasktracker fault timeout window. Each bucket is reused in a circular manner after a full timeout-window interval (defined by mapred.jobtracker.blacklist.fault-timeout-window).

definition.en: TaskTracker maximum failures

description.en: The number of task-failures on a tasktracker of a given job after which new tasks of that job aren't assigned to it.

definition.en: he filter for controlling the output of the task's userlogs sent to the console of the JobClient

description.en: The filter for controlling the output of the task's userlogs sent to the console of the JobClient. The permissible options are: NONE, KILLED, FAILED, SUCCEEDED and ALL.

definition.en: JobClient polling JobTracker interval

description.en: The interval (in milliseconds) between which the JobClient polls the JobTracker for updates about job status. You may want to set this to a lower value to make tests run faster on a single node system. Adjusting this value in production may lead to unwanted client-server traffic.

definition.en: The interval (in milliseconds) between which the JobClient reports status to the console and checks for job completion

description.en: The interval (in milliseconds) between which the JobClient reports status to the console and checks for job completion. You may want to set this to a lower value to make tests run faster on a single node system. Adjusting this value in production may lead to unwanted client-server traffic.

definition.en: Indicates if persistency of job status information is active or not.

description.en: Indicates if persistency of job status information is active or not.

definition.en: he number of hours job status information is persisted in DFS.

description.en: The number of hours job status information is persisted in DFS. The job status information will be available after it drops of the memory queue and between jobtracker restarts. With a zero value the job status information is not persisted at all in DFS.

definition.en: The directory where the job status information is persisted

description.en: The directory where the job status information is persisted in a file system to be available after it drops of the memory queue and between jobtracker restarts.

definition.en: Whether to unregister delegation tokens from renewal

description.en: if false - do not unregister/cancel delegation tokens from renewal, because same tokens may be used by spawned jobs

definition.en: Whether to collect profiler information

description.en: To set whether the system should collect profiler information for some of the tasks in this job? The information is stored in the user log directory. The value is "true" if task profiling is enabled.

definition.en: ranges of map tasks to profile

description.en: To set the ranges of map tasks to profile. mapred.task.profile has to be set to true for the value to be accounted.

definition.en: ranges of reduce tasks to profile

description.en: To set the ranges of reduce tasks to profile. mapred.task.profile has to be set to true for the value to be accounted.

definition.en: Number of lines per split in NLineInputFormat

description.en: Number of lines per split in NLineInputFormat.

definition.en: he number of Task attempts AFTER which skip mode will be kicked off

description.en: The number of Task attempts AFTER which skip mode will be kicked off. When skip mode is kicked off, the tasks reports the range of records which it will process next, to the TaskTracker. So that on failures, TT knows which ones are possibly the bad records. On further executions, those are skipped.

definition.en: Whether to increment SkipBadRecords.COUNTER_MAP_PROCESSED_GROUPS

description.en: The flag which if set to true, SkipBadRecords.COUNTER_MAP_PROCESSED_RECORDS is incremented by MapRunner after invoking the map function. This value must be set to false for applications which process the records asynchronously or buffer the input records. For example streaming. In such cases applications should increment this counter on their own.

definition.en: Whether to increment SkipBadRecords.COUNTER_REDUCE_PROCESSED_GROUPS

description.en: The flag which if set to true, SkipBadRecords.COUNTER_REDUCE_PROCESSED_GROUPS is incremented by framework after invoking the reduce function. This value must be set to false for applications which process the records asynchronously or buffer the input records. For example streaming. In such cases applications should increment this counter on their own.

definition.en: skipped records output directory

description.en: If no value is specified here, the skipped records are written to the output directory at _logs/skip. User can stop writing skipped records by giving the value "none".

definition.en: The number of acceptable skip records surrounding the bad record PER bad record in mapper

description.en: The number of acceptable skip records surrounding the bad record PER bad record in mapper. The number includes the bad record as well. To turn the feature of detection/skipping of bad records off, set the value to 0. The framework tries to narrow down the skipped range by retrying until this threshold is met OR all attempts get exhausted for this task. Set the value to Long.MAX_VALUE to indicate that framework need not try to narrow down. Whatever records(depends on application) get skipped are acceptable.

definition.en: The number of acceptable skip groups surrounding the bad group PER bad group in reducer

description.en: The number of acceptable skip groups surrounding the bad group PER bad group in reducer. The number includes the bad group as well. To turn the feature of detection/skipping of bad groups off, set the value to 0. The framework tries to narrow down the skipped range by retrying until this threshold is met OR all attempts get exhausted for this task. Set the value to Long.MAX_VALUE to indicate that framework need not try to narrow down. Whatever groups(depends on application) get skipped are acceptable.

definition.en: hadoop retry attempts to contact notification URL

description.en: Indicates how many times hadoop should attempt to contact the notification URL

definition.en: notifcation URL retry interval

description.en: Indicates time in milliseconds between notification URL retry calls

definition.en: SocketFactory to use to connect to a Map/Reduce master (JobTracker)

description.en: SocketFactory to use to connect to a Map/Reduce master (JobTracker). If null or empty, then use hadoop.rpc.socket.class.default.

definition.en: max level of the task cache

description.en: This is the max level of the task cache. For example, if the level is 2, the tasks cached are at the host level and at the rack level.

definition.en: list of queues configured for this jobtracker

description.en: Comma separated list of queues configured for this jobtracker. Jobs are added to queues and schedulers can configure different scheduling properties for the various queues. To configure a property for a queue, the name of the queue must match the name specified in this value. Queue properties that are common to all schedulers are configured here with the naming convention, mapred.queue.$QUEUE-NAME.$PROPERTY-NAME, for e.g. mapred.queue.default.submit-job-acl. The number of queues configured in this parameter could depend on the type of scheduler being used, as specified in mapred.jobtracker.taskScheduler. For example, the JobQueueTaskScheduler supports only a single queue, which is the default configured here. Before adding more queues, ensure that the scheduler you've configured supports multiple queues.

definition.en: Whether to enable ACL check

description.en: Specifies whether ACLs should be checked for authorization of users for doing various queue and job level operations. ACLs are disabled by default. If enabled, access control checks are made by JobTracker and TaskTracker when requests are made by users for queue operations like submit job to a queue and kill a job in the queue and job operations like viewing the job-details (See mapreduce.job.acl-view-job) or for modifying the job (See mapreduce.job.acl-modify-job) using Map/Reduce APIs, RPCs or via the console and web user interfaces.

definition.en: job state value

description.en: This values defines the state , default queue is in. the values can be either "STOPPED" or "RUNNING" This value can be changed at runtime.

definition.en: Queue to which a job is submitted

description.en: Queue to which a job is submitted. This must match one of the queues defined in mapred.queue.names for the system. Also, the ACL setup for the queue must allow the current user to submit a job to the queue. Before specifying a queue, ensure that the system is configured with the queue, and access is allowed for submitting jobs to the queue.

definition.en: Job specific access-control list for 'modifying' the job

description.en: Job specific access-control list for 'modifying' the job. It is only used if authorization is enabled in Map/Reduce by setting the configuration property mapred.acls.enabled to true. This specifies the list of users and/or groups who can do modification operations on the job. For specifying a list of users and groups the format to use is "user1,user2 group1,group". If set to '*', it allows all users/groups to modify this job. If set to ' '(i.e. space), it allows none. This configuration is used to guard all the modifications with respect to this job and takes care of all the following operations: o killing this job o killing a task of this job, failing a task of this job o setting the priority of this job Each of these operations are also protected by the per-queue level ACL "acl-administer-jobs" configured via mapred-queues.xml. So a caller should have the authorization to satisfy either the queue-level ACL or the job-level ACL. Irrespective of this ACL configuration, job-owner, the user who started the cluster, cluster administrators configured via mapreduce.cluster.administrators and queue administrators of the queue to which this job is submitted to configured via mapred.queue.queue-name.acl-administer-jobs in mapred-queue-acls.xml can do all the modification operations on a job. By default, nobody else besides job-owner, the user who started the cluster, cluster administrators and queue administrators can perform modification operations on a job.

definition.en: Job specific access-control list for 'viewing' the job

description.en: Job specific access-control list for 'viewing' the job. It is only used if authorization is enabled in Map/Reduce by setting the configuration property mapred.acls.enabled to true. This specifies the list of users and/or groups who can view private details about the job. For specifying a list of users and groups the format to use is "user1,user2 group1,group". If set to '*', it allows all users/groups to view this job. If set to ' '(i.e. space), it allows none. This configuration is used to guard some of the job-views and at present only protects APIs that can return possibly sensitive information of the job-owner like o job-level counters o task-level counters o tasks' diagnostic information o task-logs displayed on the TaskTracker web-UI and o job.xml showed by the JobTracker's web-UI Every other piece of information of jobs is still accessible by any other user, for e.g., JobStatus, JobProfile, list of jobs in the queue, etc. Irrespective of this ACL configuration, job-owner, the user who started the cluster, cluster administrators configured via mapreduce.cluster.administrators and queue administrators of the queue to which this job is submitted to configured via mapred.queue.queue-name.acl-administer-jobs in mapred-queue-acls.xml can do all the view operations on a job. By default, nobody else besides job-owner, the user who started the cluster, cluster administrators and queue administrators can perform view operations on a job.

definition.en: The maximum memory that a task tracker allows for the index cache

description.en: The maximum memory that a task tracker allows for the index cache that is used when serving map outputs to reducers.

definition.en: The number of records to process during combine output collection before sending a progress notification to the TaskTracker.

description.en: The number of records to process during combine output collection before sending a progress notification to the TaskTracker.

definition.en: The number of records to process during merge before sending a progress notification to the TaskTracker.

description.en: The number of records to process during merge before sending a progress notification to the TaskTracker.

definition.en: Fraction of the number of maps in the job which should be complete before reduces are scheduled for the job

description.en: Fraction of the number of maps in the job which should be complete before reduces are scheduled for the job.

definition.en: TaskController which is used to launch and manage task execution

description.en: TaskController which is used to launch and manage task execution

definition.en: Group to which TaskTracker belongs

description.en: Expert: Group to which TaskTracker belongs. If LinuxTaskController is configured via mapreduce.tasktracker.taskcontroller, the group owner of the task-controller binary should be same as this group.

definition.en: node health check interval

description.en: How often the TaskTracker checks the health of its local directories. Configuring this to a value smaller than the heartbeat interval is equivalent to setting this to heartbeat interval value.

definition.en: node health script path

description.en: Absolute path to the script which is periodically run by the node health monitoring service to determine if the node is healthy or not. If the value of this key is empty or the file does not exist in the location configured here, the node health monitoring service is not started.

definition.en: Frequency of the node health script to be run

description.en: Frequency of the node health script to be run

definition.en: node health script timeout

description.en: Time after node health script should be killed if unresponsive and considered that the script has failed.

definition.en: List of arguments which are to be passed to node health script when it is being launched comma seperated.

description.en: List of arguments which are to be passed to node health script when it is being launched comma seperated.

definition.en: Limit on the number of counters allowed per job.

description.en: Limit on the number of counters allowed per job.

definition.en: TaskTracker reserve heapsize weight

description.en: The weight of tasktracker reserve heapsize and the default value is 50.

definition.en: Task Schedule

description.en: Map/Reduce Task schedule method. If the Capacity scheduler has been selected, then additional items need to be configured.

definition.en: The map/reduce ratio.

description.en: The map/reduce ratio.

definition.en: The cpu max usage ratio.

description.en: The cpu max usage ratio.

definition.en: Whether to enable fairscheduler preemption.

description.en: Whether to enable fairscheduler preemption.

definition.en: Whether to assign multiple

description.en: Whether to assign multiple

definition.en: size based weight

description.en: size based weight

definition.en: pool name property

description.en: job.set("mapred.queue.name",pool); // pool is set to either 'high' or 'low'

definition.en: Maximum number of jobs in the system which can be initialized, concurrently, by the CapacityScheduler

description.en: Maximum number of jobs in the system which can be initialized, concurrently, by the CapacityScheduler.

definition.en: Percentage of the number of slots in the cluster that are to be available for jobs in this queue.

description.en: Percentage of the number of slots in the cluster that are to be available for jobs in this queue.

definition.en: per-queue maximum-capacity

description.en: maximum-capacity defines a limit beyond which a queue cannot use the capacity of the cluster. This provides a means to limit how much excess capacity a queue can use. By default, there is no limit. The maximum-capacity of a queue can only be greater than or equal to its minimum capacity. Default value of -1 implies a queue can use complete capacity of the cluster. This property could be to curtail certain jobs which are long running in nature from occupying more than a certain percentage of the cluster, which in the absence of pre-emption, could lead to capacity guarantees of other queues being affected. One important thing to note is that maximum-capacity is a percentage , so based on the cluster's capacity the max capacity would change. So if large number of nodes or racks get added to the cluster , max Capacity in absolute terms would increase accordingly.

definition.en: Whether to take jobs' priorities into account in scheduling decisions

description.en: If true, priorities of jobs will be taken into account in scheduling decisions.

definition.en: maximum limit on per-user's allocated percentage of resources

description.en: Each queue enforces a limit on the percentage of resources allocated to a user at any given time, if there is competition for them. This user limit can vary between a minimum and maximum value. The former depends on the number of users who have submitted jobs, and the latter is set to this property value. For example, suppose the value of this property is 25. If two users have submitted jobs to a queue, no single user can use more than 50% of the queue resources. If a third user submits a job, no single user can use more than 33% of the queue resources. With 4 or more users, no user can use more than 25% of the queue's resources. A value of 100 implies no user limits are imposed.

definition.en: The multiple of the queue capacity which can be configured to allow a single user to acquire more slots.

description.en: The multiple of the queue capacity which can be configured to allow a single user to acquire more slots.

definition.en: The maximum number of tasks, across all jobs in the queue, which can be initialized concurrently.

description.en: The maximum number of tasks, across all jobs in the queue, which can be initialized concurrently. Once the queue's jobs exceed this limit they will be queued on disk.

definition.en: The maximum number of tasks per-user, across all the of the user's jobs in the queue, which can be initialized concurrently

description.en: The maximum number of tasks per-user, across all the of the user's jobs in the queue, which can be initialized concurrently. Once the user's jobs exceed this limit they will be queued on disk.

definition.en: The multipe of (maximum-system-jobs * queue-capacity) used to determine the number of jobs which are accepted by the scheduler.

description.en: The multipe of (maximum-system-jobs * queue-capacity) used to determine the number of jobs which are accepted by the scheduler.

definition.en: If true, priorities of jobs will be taken into account in scheduling decisions by default in a job queue.

description.en: If true, priorities of jobs will be taken into account in scheduling decisions by default in a job queue.

definition.en: The percentage of the resources limited to a particular user for the job queue at any given point of time by default.

description.en: The percentage of the resources limited to a particular user for the job queue at any given point of time by default.

definition.en: The default multiple of queue-capacity which is used to determine the amount of slots a single user can consume concurrently.

description.en: The default multiple of queue-capacity which is used to determine the amount of slots a single user can consume concurrently.

definition.en: The default maximum number of tasks, across all jobs in the queue, which can be initialized concurrently

description.en: The default maximum number of tasks, across all jobs in the queue, which can be initialized concurrently. Once the queue's jobs exceed this limit they will be queued on disk.

definition.en: The default maximum number of tasks per-user, across all the of the user's jobs in the queue, which can be initialized concurrently

description.en: The default maximum number of tasks per-user, across all the of the user's jobs in the queue, which can be initialized concurrently. Once the user's jobs exceed this limit they will be queued on disk.

definition.en: The default multipe of (maximum-system-jobs * queue-capacity) used to determine the number of jobs which are accepted by the scheduler.

description.en: The default multipe of (maximum-system-jobs * queue-capacity) used to determine the number of jobs which are accepted by the scheduler.

definition.en: The amount of time in miliseconds which is used to poll the job queues for jobs to initialize.

description.en: The amount of time in miliseconds which is used to poll the job queues for jobs to initialize.

definition.en: Number of worker threads which would be used by Initialization poller to initialize jobs in a set of queue

description.en: Number of worker threads which would be used by Initialization poller to initialize jobs in a set of queue. If number mentioned in property is equal to number of job queues then a single thread would initialize jobs in a queue. If lesser then a thread would get a set of queues assigned. If the number is greater then number of threads would be equal to number of job queues.

definition.en: Whether to enable joblevel metrics

description.en: Whether to enable joblevel metrics

definition.en: Whether to enable profiling or not

description.en: The flag to determine whether Profiling Feature enable or not.

group.description_en: Basic configurations that get HDFS running.
